metadata.title: Comparative study on enantiomer resolving ability of amylose tris(3-chloro-5-methylphenylcarbamate) covalently immobilized onto silica in nano-liquid chromatography and capillary electrochromatography

omparative study on enantiomer resolving ability of amylose ris(3-chloro-5-methylphenylcarbamate) covalently immobilized nto silica in nano-liquid chromatography and capillary lectrochromatography
iovanni D’Orazio a, Chiara Fanali b, Salvatore Fanali c, Alessandra Gentili d, ezhan Chankvetadze e,∗
Istituto per i Sistemi Biologici (ISB), CNR- Consiglio Nazionale delle Ricerche, Via Salaria Km 29, 300 – 00015, Monterotondo, Rome, Italy Department of Medicine, University Campus Bio-Medico of Rome, Via Alvaro del Portillo 21, 00128, Rome, Italy Teaching Committee of Ph.D. School in Natural Science and Engineering, University of Verona, Strada Le Grazie, 15 – 37129, Verona, Italy Department of Chemistry “Sapienza” University of Rome, P.le Aldo Moro 5, 00185, Rome, Italy Institute of Physical and Analytical Chemistry, School of Exact and Natural Sciences, Tbilisi State University, Chavchavadze Ave 3, 0179, Tbilisi, Georgia
r t i c l e i n f o
rticle history: eceived 22 June 2019 eceived in revised form 2 August 2019 ccepted 3 August 2019 vailable online xxx
eywords: ano-LC
a b s t r a c t
In the present study separation of enantiomers of some chiral neutral and weakly acidic analytes was investigated on the chiral stationary phase (CSP) made by covalent immobilization of amylose tris(3chloro-5-methylphenylcarbamate) onto silica in nano-liquid chromatography (nano-LC) and capillary electrochromatography (CEC) in acetonitrile and aqueous acetonitrile. Few comparisons were made also between the enantioseparations in nano-LC and high-performance liquid chromatography (HPLC) with the chiral column of 4.6 × 250 mm dimension. Slightly better separation of enantiomers was observed in HPLC mode compared to nano-LC mode. It was shown that in the capillary columns packed with the CSP
apillary electrochromatography nantioseparations ovalently immobilized olysaccharide-based chiral stationary hase mylose tris
containing about 20% (w/w) of a covalently immobilized neutral chiral selector, amylose tris(3-chloro5-methylphenylcarbamate), sufficient electroosmotic flow has been generated and enantioseparations with reasonable analysis time were performed also in CEC mode. It was shown once again that CEC offers a clear advantage over nano-LC from the viewpoint of plate numbers and peak resolution.

3-chloro-5-methylphenylcarbamate)
. Introduction
Chiral stationary phases based on polysaccharide derivatives are idely used for separation of enantiomers in liquid-phase tech-
iques such as high-performance liquid chromatography (HPLC) 1–3], nano-liquid chromatography (nano-LC) [4–7], supercritical uid chromatography (SFC) [8,9], capillary electrochromatography CEC) [4,10–16] and lab-on a chip devices [17]. Many publications n the past have demonstrated the advantages of CEC for enanioseparations over pressure-driven techniques such as HPLC and ano-LC [4,10–14]. At the same time, it must be noted that per-
Please cite this article in press as: G. D’Orazio, et al., Comparative st methylphenylcarbamate) covalently immobilized onto silica in nano Chromatogr. A (xxxx), https://doi.org/10.1016/j.chroma.2019.460425
orming CEC experiments is more demanding compared to nano-LC xperiment. The special difficulties in CEC experiment are associted with the generation of the electroosmotic flow (EOF), avoiding
∗ Corresponding author. E-mail address: jpba bezhan@yahoo.com (B. Chankvetadze).
ttps://doi.org/10.1016/j.chroma.2019.460425 021-9673/© 2019 Elsevier B.V. All rights reserved.
air bubbles in the capillary columns upon application of high voltage and preparation of on-capillary frits for retaining the packing material. Therefore, attempting CEC experiment is reasonable only in the case if the potential advantage of this technique from the viewpoint of high plate count and accordingly, high peak resolution is really achieved. The comparative nano-LC and CEC studies in the same or very similar experimental setup may indicate whether or not this is the case.
Application of polysaccharide-based CSPs in CEC offers some advantages, as well as certain challenges are associated with this application. To the advantages belong the wide coverage of chiral analytes and remarkable enantiomer resolving power of these materials, as well as the availability of various derivatives. To the challenges belong neutral (uncharged) nature of polysaccharide
udy on enantiomer resolving ability of amylose tris(3-chloro-5-liquid chromatography and capillary electrochromatography, J.
derivatives, as well as commonly high content (up to 25% w/w) of polysaccharide-based chiral selectors in CSP. These last two characteristics make a generation of sufficient EOF, that is the major driving force of analytes in CEC experiment, problematic. Various

ARTICLEHROMA-460425; No. of Pages 8 G. D’Orazio et al. / J. C
olutions are available for this problem which made application f polysaccharide-based CSPs quite popular for enantioseparations lso in CEC. This kind of chiral selectors can be coated or covaently attached to the inert carrier (mostly silica). Many applications f coated-type polysaccharide-based CSPs in CEC are described in he literature [4,10–16]. Few papers describe also application of ovalently immobilized polysaccharide-based CSPs in CEC for sepration of enantiomers but no comparison between nano-LC and EC has been reported in these studies [18–20] except the few cases 21,22]. The preparation of CSP by coating of a chiral selector is a ast single-step process, the content of chiral selector can be easly varied and there is no specific requirement to the chemistry of ilica surface. The disadvantage of coated CSPs is their low stability n some solvents which may be used as components of a mobile hase or for dissolution of a sample. The problem of CSP stability an be solved by covalent immobilization of a chiral selector onto he surface of silica. Most of the covalent immobilization technoloies require pre-activation of polysaccharide derivative and silica urface, are commonly multistep processes and not applicable to ris-derivatives (tri-substituted per glucopyranose unit) of polysacharides [6,23–28]. However, immobilization of tris-derivatives f polysaccharides onto the surface of silica is also possible. The oal of the present study was to evaluate the applicability of the SP made by covalent immobilization of amylose tris(3-chloro-5ethylphenylcarbamate) onto silica [29] for enantioseparations in
ano-LC and CEC.
. Experimental
.1. Chemicals and materials
Methanol (MeOH), ethanol (EtOH), 2-propanol (2-PrOH), 1- ropanol (n-PrOH), ammonia solution (30%, w/w), glacial acetic cid (99.8%, w/w) (AcH) and formic acid (99.0%, w/w) (FA) were urchased from Carlo Erba (Rodano, Milan, Italy). Acetone was btained from Romil (Cambridge, UK), while acetonitrile of HPLC rade (ACN) and HPLC ultrapure water (filtered at 0.2 m and packged under nitrogen) were from VWR (International PBI S.r.l. Milan, taly).
Racemic mixtures of flavanone (Fla), 4-́methoxyflavanone 4-́MeO-Fla), 6-methoxyflavanone (6-MeO-Fla), 7-
ethoxyflavanone (7-MeO-Fla), 2-́hydroxyflavanone (2´−OH-Fla), -́hydroxyflavanone (4´−OH-Fla), 6-hydroxyflavanone (6−OHla), 7-hydroxyflavanone (7−OH-Fla) (flavonoids) and lorazepam, xazepam, and temazepam were obtained from Sigma-Aldrich St. Louis, MO, USA). Diclofop, fenoxaprop, dichlorprop, haloxyfop, uazifop (herbicides in the free acidic form) were purchased from r. Ehrenstorfer GmbH (Augsburg, Germany). The non-steroidal nti-inflammatory drugs (NSAIDs) racemic indoprofen, naproxen, arprofen, cicloprofen, flurbiprofen, suprofen and the single enaniomers, S(+)-flurbiprofen and S(+)-suprofen were kindly provided y Dr. Cecilia Bartolucci (Institute of Crystallography, CNR, Monerotondo, Roma, Italy). Ketoprofen, ketorolac, and ibuprofen were rom Sigma-Aldrich. Racemic thalidomide and its (+)-enantiomer
ere kindly provided by the Institute of Pharmaceutical and edicinal Chemistry, University of Münster, Münster, Germany.
rofenofos, dialifos, fenamifos (organophosphorus pesticides) ere purchased from Riedel-de Haën (Seelze, Germany), while arfarin and hexobarbital were obtained from Sigma-Aldrich.
The stock of racemic mixtures and pure enantiomer standard olutions were prepared in MeOH or ACN at 1.0 mg/mL and main-
Please cite this article in press as: G. D’Orazio, et al., Comparative st methylphenylcarbamate) covalently immobilized onto silica in nano Chromatogr. A (xxxx), https://doi.org/10.1016/j.chroma.2019.460425
ained at −18 ◦C. The stock solutions of racemic mixtures and ure enantiomer standards were prepared by mixing the approriate volumes of stock solutions and diluting at 100 g/mL with 2O/2-PrOH/MeOH (80:10:10, v/v/v). 50 mL of 500 mM stock buffer
HPLC-grade MeOH and ACN and reagent grade formic acid, used for HPLC experiments, were supplied from Karl Roth (Karlsruhe, Germany). Amylose tris(3-chloro-5-methylphenylcarbamate) (Fig. S1) was synthesized as described earlier [30]. The product was isolated by precipitation in MeOH, filtration, washed with excess methanol and dried in the vacuum oven at 70 ◦C for 12 h. The carbamate was dissolved and coated on silica of 5 m nominal particle size (Daiso, Osaka, Japan). The coated material was immobilized onto the silica support using a proprietary technology.
HPLC experiments were performed using ACN containing 0.1% FA (v/v) as the mobile phase. The separation temperature was 20 ◦C. The flow rate was 1 mL/min and UV detector was set at 220 nm.
Fused silica capillary tubing (100 m I.D. × 375 m O.D.) were obtained from Composite Metal Service (Hallow, UK).
udy on enantiomer resolving ability of amylose tris(3-chloro-5-liquid chromatography and capillary electrochromatography, J.
2.2. Instrumentation
An ultrasonic bath model FS 100b Decon (Hove, UK) was utilized to sonicate mobile phases, to dissolve analytes, to slurry packing

aterial and sonicate fused silica capillary during the packing proess.
A Stereozoom 4 optical microscope (Cambridge Instruments, ienna, Austria) with illuminator was used to check the status of the apillary columns and monitoring the fused silica capillary during he capillary column packing procedure.
An HPLC pump (Perkin Elmer Series 10, Palo Alto, CA, USA) was sed for packing and equilibrate the capillary columns.
A Crison Basic pH 20 (Crison Instruments SA, Barcelona, Spain), ith a combined electrode and a temperature sensor was used
uring titration of stock buffer solution at pH 2.5 or 3.5.
.3. Packing of the capillary columns
The capillary columns were prepared in our laboratory following packing procedure previously published by our group [31] based n the slurry packing method.
In order to have the optimum suspension of the CSP, different rganic solvents were tested. 50 mg/mL of the CSP in ACN was elected. The slurry, after sonication (5 min), was quickly transerred into an HPLC pre-column 50 × 4.1 mm I.D. (Valco, Houston, X, USA) connected at the inlet end to the LC-pump while the outlet nd was joined to the silica capillary (45 cm length). The pumping olvent was MeOH and the maximum pressure during packing pro-
Please cite this article in press as: G. D’Orazio, et al., Comparative st methylphenylcarbamate) covalently immobilized onto silica in nano Chromatogr. A (xxxx), https://doi.org/10.1016/j.chroma.2019.460425
edure was in the range 30–35 MPa (300–350 bar). A mechanical rit was used to retain the CSP during the packing procedure. After acking the capillary for about 30 cm, the pre-column was disconected and the capillary flushed with ACN for 15 min. Afterward, at
30 MPa, the inlet and outlet frits were fabricated by sintering the CSP with a laboratory-made electrical wire heated at about 650 ◦C for 10 s. After removing the mechanical frit, the excess of the stationary phase was eliminated applying the back-flushing mode. The detection window was prepared at 1.5 cm from the outlet frit empty side by removing the polyimide coating. The capillary column was 25.0 and 34.9 cm packed and the total length, respectively, while the effective length was 26.5 cm. The same capillary was first used for nano-LC and then for CEC experiments.
2.4. Capillary electrochromatography
An Agilent 3DCE system, (Agilent Technologies, Waldbronn, Germany), equipped with a diode-array UV detector and an autosampler was employed for CEC experiments.
The capillary column was firstly equilibrated with the mobile phase with the HPLC pump at 10 MPa and then positioned into the CE instrument. An additional conditioning step was introduced applying a voltage ramp (+5 to +25 kV) for 30 min achieving a good baseline. At the end of the working day, both ends of the capillary were submerged into the vials containing MeOH/water 90:10 (v/v).
In order to avoid bubble formation, CEC experiments were performed applying to both vials a pressure of 10 bar. The column temperature was controlled by an air thermostating system set at
udy on enantiomer resolving ability of amylose tris(3-chloro-5-liquid chromatography and capillary electrochromatography, J.
20 ◦C. The sample was hydrodynamically injected applying 10 bar pressure for 0.5 min at the anodic end. The separation voltage was in the range +2.5 to +30 kV. The UV detector was set at 214 nm, rise time: 0.5 s and 20 Hz.

A modified LC injection valve (Enantiosep, Münster, Germany) as used for analytes injection. Its external configuration included
30 L external loop, that allowed both sample loading, as well as ts use as a mobile phase reservoir during the chiral separation. njection was based on the pressure-pulse driven stopped-flow njection time method [32]. The capillary column flow rate, after the plitting system, was estimated connecting a 10 L syringe (Hamilon, Reno, NV, USA) to the outlet column through a Teflon® tube TF-350; LC-Packing, CA, USA) and measuring the mobile phase volme for approximately 5 min. The flow rate was changed in the ange of 30–1550 nL/min. In order to reduce dead volume and the and broadening effect, the column inlet was directly connected to he modified valve [14].
A Spectra 100 UV instrument (Thermo Separation Products, San ose, CA, USA), was utilized for the on-column UV detection. Data
ere acquired at 214 nm, 20 Hz and rise time 0.5 s. The HPLC pump as managed by Chemstation software (Rev.A.09.01, Agilent Tech-
ologies) while the UV detector data were acquired and processed ith the ChromQuest version 3.0 software (Thermo-Finnigan, San
ose, CA, USA). HPLC experiments were performed with an Agilent 1200 HPLC

nstrument (Agilent Technologies, Waldbronn, Germany) equipped ith a G1367C HiP ALS-SL autosampler, G1316C Infinity TCC emperature controller from Agilent 1290 Infinity HPLC, G1311A uaternary pump and G1314D VWD variable wavelength detec-
Amylose tris(3-chloro-5-methylphenylcarbamate) as useful chiral selector for separation of enantiomers in HPLC was first described in 1997 [30]. However, since the chiral columns based on this derivative of amylose became commercially available just in few recent years not many studies were published on the chiral recognition ability of this material [29,30,33–35]. Therefore, one of the aims of the current project was to investigate a coverage of chiral analytes of different structural groups with this chiral selector. Thus, the separation of enantiomers of chiral weak acids representing barbiturates, coumarin derivatives, and arylpropionic acid derivatives was studied alongside with neutral chiral analytes such as flavanone derivatives, thalidomide and phenoxy acid herbicides. The separations were performed in ACN containing up to 10% water (v/v). As it can be seen from Table 1 amylose tris(3chloro-5-methylphenylcarbamate) exhibited quite universal chiral recognition ability towards the enantiomers of studied chiral analytes, although the peak efficiency was relatively low. In few cases rather high resolution of enantiomers was observed (Fig. 1).
In our earlier studies with some classical (non-UHPLC) instrumentation, we observed a significant loss of peak efficiency with reducing column internal diameter. In order to evaluate the role of
udy on enantiomer resolving ability of amylose tris(3-chloro-5-liquid chromatography and capillary electrochromatography, J.
the column internal diameter on peak efficiency few separations of enantiomers were performed in both, standard HPLC columns with the dimension 4.6 mm x 250 mm, as well as on the capillary column of 100 m x 250 mm dimension. In some cases quite similar results

ere obtained on the columns of both dimension (Fig. 2) while in ost cases peak resolution in HPLC was better compared to that n nano-LC (Fig. 3). The potential reason for such difference could e quality of column packing, an aspect ratio of the column, colmn overloading or extra column dead volume that becomes more ritical with narrow diameter columns. These aspects need further nvestigation.
.2. Enantioseparations in CEC
As it is well documented theoretically and illustrated in earlier tudies, CEC offers significantly higher peak efficiency compared to ano-LC [4,10–14]. However, in order to profit from this advantage f CEC, the packing material has to be able to generate sufficient OF upon application of high voltage. As it is shown in Fig. 4 the acking material used in this study meets the above-mentioned equirement in aqueous ACN containing ammonium formate as the lectrolyte. In addition, the EOF, that was directed to the cathode ue to the application of native silica as a support for the chiral elector, changes as a linear function of the applied voltage. This onfirms that no excessive Joule heat is generated in the separation apillary.
One may expect that based on the nature of the most anayzed compounds under this study and the acidity of the mobile hase used the separations with reversed-phase-like mechanism ill dominate. As it is shown in Fig. 5, in contrast to the expecation with increasing water content in the buffer the retention actor of the analyte enantiomers were decreased. This opposite rend was also observed especially in the lower percentage of ater content by D’Orazio et al. for the tryptophan derivatives ith Vancomycin-based CSP in nano-LC experiments [36]. The ajor reason seems to be the so-called “HILIC-like” separation echanism with polysaccharide-based chiral selectors in aqueus acetonitrile previously observed in HPLC [33,37–40]. Shortly, he retention of analyte enantiomers in pure acetonitrile seems to e significantly controlled by hydrogen-bonding type interactions etween the analyte and chiral selector. The addition of water to the obile phase initially reduces the hydrogen-bonding type interacions between the analytes and chiral selector, thus replacing the nalytes from the transient diastereomeric associates with the chial selector and reducing retention of the analyte enantiomers. At he certain percentage of water in the mobile phase, the hydrophoic type interactions become the major contributor to the retention and separation) and thus, the retention starts to increase with ncreasing water content in the mobile phase (typical reversedhase behavior). New observation in CEC is that with increasing ater content in the buffer the plate numbers and peak resolution ncreased for most of the analytes (Fig. 5). The effect of ammonium formate concentration in the buffer on he peak resolution was less significant (data not shown).
.3. Comparison between nano-LC and CEC
Please cite this article in press as: G. D’Orazio, et al., Comparative st methylphenylcarbamate) covalently immobilized onto silica in nano Chromatogr. A (xxxx), https://doi.org/10.1016/j.chroma.2019.460425
Although theoretically it is possible to observe higher peak effiiency and, as a result, higher peak resolution in CEC compared o nano-LC in the same experimental setup, in quite many pubished articles this advantage of CEC is either not addressed or
not properly evidenced. Since performing CEC experiment is more demanding rather than performing nano-LC experiment the former makes sense only in the case if its potential from the viewpoint of high plate numbers is at least partially employed. The comparative results summarized for 30 acidic and neutral chiral analytes in Table 2 clearly indicate the advantage of CEC over nano-LC. For all analytes without any exception peak resolution (Rs) in CEC mode was higher compared to nano-LC. The higher peak resolution was achieved due to higher peak efficiency that was approximately 2.0–2.5 times higher in CEC compared to nano-LC. Some representative examples of enantioseparations in nano-LC and CEC modes are shown in Fig. 6.
In order to get more detailed information about the origin of higher plate number in CEC mode than in nano-LC, the van Deemter plots were constructed and the related coefficients were calculated for few analytes in both separation modes using the following equation:
H = A + B/u + Cu (1)
where H is the height equivalent to the theoretical plate (HETP) in m and u is the linear flow rate in m/ s.
The results shown in Fig. 7 illustrate that the advantage of CEC holds in the entire studied mobile phase flow rate. In addition, the dependence of the theoretical plate height on the linear flow rate of the mobile phase is less steep in CEC compared to nano-LC. This may allow performing fast enantioseparations in CEC mode without significant lost of plate counts. The van Deemter coefficients summarized for both separation modes in Table 3 indicate that the higher plate numbers observed in CEC experiments originate mostly from the lower A-term and improved mass transfer (C coefficient) between the mobile and stationary phase in CEC mode. This is in good agreement with earlier observations [41].
4. Conclusions
As illustrated in this study amylose tris(3-chloro-5methylphenylcarbamate) covalently immobilized onto silica represents an useful chiral stationary phase for separation of enantiomers in nano-liquid chromatography and capillary electrochromatography. Resolution of enantiomers obtained in nano-LC was slightly worse compared to the results obtained in HPLC. In capillary electrochromatography with increasing water content in acetonitrile up to 10% (v/v) the retention of enantiomers decreased and plate height and peak resolution improved. Capillary electrochromatography provides significantly higher plate counts and enantiomer resolution compared to nano-liquid chromatography in the same capillary column.

referenceMentions.context: Chiral stationary phases based on polysaccharide derivatives are idely used for separation of enantiomers in liquid-phase techiques such as high-performance liquid chromatography (HPLC) 1–3], nano-liquid chromatography (nano-LC) [4–7], supercritical uid chromatography (SFC) [8,9], capillary electrochromatography CEC) [4,10–16] and lab-on a chip devices [17].

metadata.abstractText: In the present study separation of enantiomers of some chiral neutral and weakly acidic analytes was investigated on the chiral stationary phase (CSP) made by covalent immobilization of amylose tris(3chloro-5-methylphenylcarbamate) onto silica in nano-liquid chromatography (nano-LC) and capillary electrochromatography (CEC) in acetonitrile and aqueous acetonitrile. Few comparisons were made also between the enantioseparations in nano-LC and high-performance liquid chromatography (HPLC) with the chiral column of 4.6 × 250 mm dimension. Slightly better separation of enantiomers was observed in HPLC mode compared to nano-LC mode. It was shown that in the capillary columns packed with the CSP apillary electrochromatography nantioseparations ovalently immobilized olysaccharide-based chiral stationary hase mylose tris containing about 20% (w/w) of a covalently immobilized neutral chiral selector, amylose tris(3-chloro5-methylphenylcarbamate), sufficient electroosmotic flow has been generated and enantioseparations with reasonable analysis time were performed also in CEC mode. It was shown once again that CEC offers a clear advantage over nano-LC from the viewpoint of plate numbers and peak resolution. © 2019 Elsevier B.V. All rights reserved. 3-chloro-5-methylphenylcarbamate)
metadata.creator: Elsevier
